sen.e: At first, it was called Ryosen-ji Temple and became the place of imperial prayer for Emperor Koko and Emperor Uda.

sen.j: 江戸時代には江戸幕府から朱印状を与えられ、塔頭十余宇を有したが、明治以降衰退し、現在は本堂（釈迦堂）・庫裏などを残すのみとなった。
sen.e: In the Edo period, it was given Shuinjo (shogunate license to trade) by the Edo bakufu and had around 10 tatchu (sub-temples in the site of main temple); however, it has come to decline since Meiji period, and accordingly, today it only has a Hondo (Shaka-do Hall), Kuri (the priest's living quarters or the kitchen of a temple), etc.

sen.j: また、当時正法寺で授けたお札は「柏のお札」といって柏の葉の形の中に「伊勢熊野参詣輩」「許永代汚穢」（永代の汚穢を許す）の文言が刷られていた。
sen.e: In addition, Ofuda (paper charms) provided at Shobo-ji Temple at that time were called "Ofuda of Kashiwa Oak" whose shape was a leaf of Kashiwa Oak, and words, such as "伊勢熊野参詣輩" (visit to Ise and Kumano) and "許永代汚穢" (forgive the impurity of Eitai), were printed on Ofuda.
